import asyncio

async def fetch_data(url):
    await asyncio.sleep(1)
    return f"Data from {url}"

async def main():
    result = await fetch_data("https://api.example.com")
    print(result)

import asyncio

async def main():
    tasks = [
        fetch_data(url1),
        fetch_data(url2),
        fetch_data(url3)
    ]
    results = await asyncio.gather(*tasks)
    return results

from enum import Enum

class Status(Enum):
    PENDING = "pending"
    ACTIVE = "active"
    COMPLETED = "completed"

current_status = Status.ACTIVE
if current_status == Status.ACTIVE:
    process()

from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor

def process_item(item):
    return item * 2

with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=4) as executor:
    results = list(executor.map(process_item, items))

from collections import namedtuple

Point = namedtuple("Point", ["x", "y"])
p = Point(10, 20)
print(f"x={p.x}, y={p.y}")

import copy

original = {"a": [1, 2, 3]}
shallow = copy.copy(original)
deep = copy.deepcopy(original)

original["a"].append(4)
print(shallow["a"])  # [1, 2, 3, 4]
print(deep["a"])     # [1, 2, 3]

import weakref

class ExpensiveObject:
    pass

obj = ExpensiveObject()
weak_ref = weakref.ref(obj)

if weak_ref() is not None:
    print("Object still exists")

def moving_average():
    total = 0
    count = 0
    average = None
    while True:
        value = yield average
        total += value
        count += 1
        average = total / count

avg = moving_average()
next(avg)
result = avg.send(10)

SELECT name, price FROM products
ORDER BY price DESC;

WHERE email LIKE "%@gmail.com";

SELECT * FROM orders
WHERE status IN ("pending", "processing");

SELECT * FROM products
WHERE price BETWEEN 50 AND 100;

VALUES ("John Doe", "john@example.com");

DELETE FROM orders
WHERE status = "cancelled";

SELECT * FROM users
WHERE deleted_at IS NULL;

SELECT MAX(price) as highest_price
FROM products;

SELECT MIN(created_at) as first_order
FROM orders;

SELECT AVG(price) as average_price
FROM products;

SELECT SUM(amount) as total_revenue
FROM orders;

SELECT * FROM users
WHERE role = "admin" OR role = "moderator";

SELECT * FROM products
WHERE NOT discontinued = true;

SELECT * FROM users
LIMIT 10 OFFSET 20;

SELECT * FROM orders o
INNER JOIN users u ON o.user_id = u.id;

SELECT * FROM orders
WHERE created_at >= "2024-01-01";

SELECT * FROM products
ORDER BY category ASC, price DESC;

INSERT INTO tags (name)
VALUES ("tech"), ("news"), ("sports");

SELECT u.name, COUNT(o.id) as order_count
FROM users u
LEFT JOIN orders o ON u.id = o.user_id
GROUP BY u.id, u.name;

SELECT name,
       CASE
         WHEN price < 50 THEN "cheap"
         WHEN price < 100 THEN "moderate"
         ELSE "expensive"
       END as price_category
FROM products;

SELECT user_id, COUNT(*) as total
FROM orders
GROUP BY user_id
HAVING total >= 5;

SELECT o.id, u.name, p.name as product
FROM orders o
JOIN users u ON o.user_id = u.id
JOIN products p ON o.product_id = p.id;

SELECT CONCAT(first_name, " ", last_name) as full_name
FROM users;

SELECT DATE_FORMAT(created_at, "%Y-%m-%d") as date,
       COUNT(*) as count
FROM orders
GROUP BY date;

SELECT NULLIF(discount, 0) as valid_discount
FROM products;

SELECT name, ROUND(price, 2) as rounded_price
FROM products;

UPDATE orders o
JOIN users u ON o.user_id = u.id
SET o.status = "priority"
WHERE u.tier = "premium";

SELECT name, SUBSTRING(description, 1, 50) as preview
FROM products;

SELECT name, DATEDIFF(NOW(), created_at) as days_old
FROM users;
CREATE INDEX idx_user_email ON users(email);

WITH monthly_sales AS (
  SELECT DATE_FORMAT(date, "%Y-%m") as month,
         SUM(amount) as total
  FROM sales
  GROUP BY month
)
SELECT * FROM monthly_sales
WHERE total > 10000;

WITH RECURSIVE category_tree AS (
  SELECT id, name, parent_id, 1 as level
  FROM categories
  WHERE parent_id IS NULL
  UNION ALL
  SELECT c.id, c.name, c.parent_id, ct.level + 1
  FROM categories c
  JOIN category_tree ct ON c.parent_id = ct.id
)
SELECT * FROM category_tree;

WITH active_users AS (
  SELECT * FROM users WHERE status = "active"
),
user_orders AS (
  SELECT user_id, COUNT(*) as order_count
  FROM orders
  GROUP BY user_id
)
SELECT u.name, uo.order_count
FROM active_users u
JOIN user_orders uo ON u.id = uo.user_id;

SELECT user_id,
       SUM(CASE WHEN status = "pending" THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) as pending,
       SUM(CASE WHEN status = "completed" THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) as completed,
       SUM(CASE WHEN status = "cancelled" THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) as cancelled
FROM orders
GROUP BY user_id;

SELECT name, revenue,
       SUM(revenue) OVER (ORDER BY revenue DESC) * 100.0 /
       SUM(revenue) OVER () as cumulative_pct
FROM products;

SELECT u.name, u.total_orders
FROM (
  SELECT user_id, COUNT(*) as total_orders
  FROM orders
  WHERE created_at >= DATE_SUB(NOW(), INTERVAL 30 DAY)
  GROUP BY user_id
  HAVING total_orders > 5
) o
JOIN users u ON o.user_id = u.id;

SELECT id,
       JSON_EXTRACT(metadata, "$.color") as color,
       JSON_EXTRACT(metadata, "$.size") as size
FROM products;

SELECT * FROM users u
LEFT JOIN orders o ON u.id = o.user_id
UNION
SELECT * FROM users u
RIGHT JOIN orders o ON u.id = o.user_id
WHERE u.id IS NULL;

SELECT p1.*
FROM products p1
WHERE price > (
  SELECT AVG(price)
  FROM products p2
  WHERE p2.category = p1.category
);

CREATE VIEW active_user_stats AS
SELECT u.id, u.name, COUNT(o.id) as order_count,
       SUM(o.amount) as total_spent
FROM users u
LEFT JOIN orders o ON u.id = o.user_id
WHERE u.status = "active"
GROUP BY u.id, u.name;

DELIMITER //
CREATE PROCEDURE GetUserOrders(IN userId INT)
BEGIN
  SELECT * FROM orders
  WHERE user_id = userId
  ORDER BY created_at DESC;
END //
DELIMITER ;

CREATE TABLE orders (
  id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
  user_id INT NOT NULL,
  amount DECIMAL(10,2),
  FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(id)
    ON DELETE CASCADE
    ON UPDATE CASCADE
);

SELECT "user" as type, id, name, created_at FROM users
UNION ALL
SELECT "product" as type, id, name, created_at FROM products
UNION ALL
SELECT "order" as type, id, CONCAT("Order #", id), created_at FROM orders
ORDER BY created_at DESC
LIMIT 100;

SELECT name, salary,
       PERCENT_RANK() OVER (ORDER BY salary) as percentile
FROM employees
WHERE percentile >= 0.9;
